146596796.review:
Zuma was released just before the wave of casual PC gaming blew up the Internet. It was one of the early examples of such games, so I wouldn't worry about the label "casual" too much. The main idea was inspired by Japanese arcade game called Puzz Loop.

Technically Zuma belongs to the puzzle genre. You as a player should react fast and shoot precisely. The amount of lives is limited, and difficulty increases after each level. So it seems too advanced for inexperienced casual players (especially on the last levels), but might look easy and repetitive for hardcore ones. Despite it all, the game is still enjoyable and worth playing.

I am so mad that I have found this game on Steam.

As a guy in my teens/early 20's, I used to play this game ALL THE TIME on my piece of crap laptop. I would furiously conquer level after level, trying always to get better combos, more gap-shots, and complete levels faster and faster. I don't know how much time I sunk into doing this stupid game, so the fact that I've got pulled back in once again is insane.

This is an easy buy. You're a little frog in the middle who spits marbles and trails of marbles going around you. You try to match 3, which clears those marbles. You try to do "bonus" things like shooting marbles in between gaps or clearing out large numbers of marbles at the same time. It's really not that complicated... it's just about as simple as it looks.

But I'm telling you, it's addicting. It really is. Before you realize what's going on, you'll be sucked in and won't want to stop.

This game is SUPER old, so you could probably run it on your microwave. No need to worry about laptop specs. 

You will find yourself furiously trying to survive as the levels get more and more difficult. Do you have what it takes!? 

ZUMA!!!!!!!!!!

[h1]Nostalgic Blast from the Past - Zuma Deluxe Game Review[/h1]
ㅤ
[h1]Visuals[/h1]
Zuma Deluxe takes us on a delightful journey back to the era of classic games with its charming and vibrant visuals. The game features colorful balls rolling along intricately designed paths, captivating players with its simple yet visually appealing graphics. The vivid and lively colors evoke a sense of nostalgia, reminding us of the joy and simplicity of gaming in the early days.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay of Zuma Deluxe is a testament to the timeless appeal of old-school games. It offers a unique blend of puzzle-solving and fast-paced action that keeps players engaged and addicted for hours on end. The goal is simple: launch colored balls from a stone frog's mouth to match three or more balls of the same color, causing them to disappear and preventing the never-ending chain of balls from reaching the golden skull. The intuitive controls and addictive mechanics make every level a thrilling challenge, rewarding precise aim and quick thinking.

[h1]Nostalgia[/h1]
Zuma Deluxe holds a special place in the hearts of gamers who grew up during the golden age of casual gaming. It transports us back to a time when we huddled around our computers, eagerly clicking away, and chasing high scores. The familiar sound effects, catchy music, and familiar gameplay mechanics evoke a strong sense of nostalgia, reminding us of the joy and innocence of simpler times. Playing Zuma Deluxe today is like reconnecting with an old friend, reliving cherished memories and relishing in the nostalgia of classic gaming.

[h1]Sound Design[/h1]
The sound design of Zuma Deluxe is a symphony of nostalgia. The satisfying "pop" sound when balls are eliminated, the joyful chimes of level completion, and the energetic background music create an immersive audio experience. Each sound effect is perfectly crafted to heighten the excitement and immerse players in the gameplay. Even the nostalgic click-clack sound of the balls rolling along the paths adds an extra layer of immersion, transporting us back to the days of clicking mice and tapping keyboards.

[h1]Replayability[/h1]
Zuma Deluxe offers endless replayability, making it a staple in every gamer's collection. With multiple levels, each with increasing difficulty and new challenges, the game ensures that there is always something fresh to tackle. Additionally, striving for high scores and attempting to beat your own records provides a never-ending source of motivation and excitement. Zuma Deluxe is a game that can be replayed time and time again, reminding us of the addictive and timeless nature of classic games.

[h1]Longevity[/h1]
Even after all these years, Zuma Deluxe remains a beloved title that stands the test of time. Its simplistic yet addictive gameplay mechanics and nostalgic charm have cemented its place in gaming history. It serves as a reminder that classic games can still bring immense joy and entertainment, proving that sometimes the simplest concepts are the most enduring. Zuma Deluxe is a testament to the longevity of well-designed games and will continue to captivate players, both old and new, for years to come.

In a world of ever-evolving gaming technology, Zuma Deluxe stands tall as a nostalgic gem that captures the essence of the golden age of casual gaming. It serves as a heartwarming reminder of the joy and simplicity that old games brought to our lives. Whether you're revisiting it for a trip down memory lane or discovering it for the first time, Zuma Deluxe is an experience that will fill you with warmth and make you appreciate the timeless appeal of classic games.

138204464.review:
Zuma by PopCap Games - A Colorful Puzzle Adventure

Rating: ★★★★☆

Zuma, created by PopCap Games, is a delightful and addictive puzzle game that combines strategy, speed, and precision. Embark on an exciting adventure as you guide a fearless frog through a series of challenging levels, spitting colored balls to match and eliminate them before they reach the golden skull at the end of each path. With its engaging gameplay, vibrant visuals, and clever mechanics, Zuma is a standout title from the renowned developers at PopCap Games.

Graphics and Presentation: ★★★★☆
PopCap Games is known for their charming and visually appealing games, and Zuma is no exception. The game features colorful and detailed graphics, with lush jungle backdrops and whimsical animations. The vibrant colors and smooth animations create an immersive experience, bringing the world of Zuma to life.

Gameplay: ★★★★★
Zuma's gameplay is simple yet highly addictive. As the frog in the center of the screen, your goal is to eliminate a stream of colored balls by shooting balls of the same color from your mouth. Match three or more balls to make them disappear, creating chain reactions and earning bonus points. The mechanics are easy to grasp, but as you progress, the game introduces challenging level designs, power-ups, and special balls that add complexity and strategic depth. The precise aiming and quick reflexes required make every level a thrilling and satisfying experience.

Content and Variety: ★★★★☆
Zuma offers a substantial amount of content to keep players engaged. The game features multiple worlds with distinct themes, each containing a series of levels to conquer. As you progress, new obstacles, power-ups, and bonus stages are introduced, ensuring that the gameplay remains fresh and exciting. The increasing difficulty curve provides a satisfying challenge for players of all skill levels.

Sound and Music: ★★★☆☆
While the sound effects and music in Zuma are fitting and pleasant, they don't particularly stand out. The catchy tunes and cheerful sound effects complement the gameplay well, but they can become repetitive over time.

Overall, Zuma is a captivating puzzle game that strikes the perfect balance between simplicity and challenge. Its engaging gameplay, charming visuals, and variety of content make it a must-play for puzzle enthusiasts looking for an addictive and entertaining experience. PopCap Games has once again delivered a gem that will keep players hooked for hours on end.

135236403.review: zuma might be the single greatest color-matching game, at least made by popcap. it's completely simple in what it accomplishes, yet it nails every core foundation of what makes this type of game great:  gameplay (obviously), music, setting, and artstyle. in comparison to a similar color-matching game like bejeweled, zuma has significantly more interesting gameplay because there's a larger variety of skillful ways to match colors by shooting through gaps and building combos around single or double color matches. not only that, but the visuals and music stand out because they work in tandem to support each other, sporting a wonderfully pleasant jungle-themed soundtrack while you explore ancient aztec (or something like that) temples, with dusty and surprisingly varied tracks. this is a striking comparison to bejeweled's visuals because bejeweled is quite literally just gems on a board with a 2D background image of a fancy structure. basically buy zuma because it's the goat

131350263.review:
[quote]Follow my Curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41363546-Fruit-N-Doggie-Reviews/]Fruit N Doggie Reviews,[/url] so you can be updated whenever I post a new review.[/quote]
[h1]First Impressions[/h1] 
It's time to finish my coverage of the games I bought from the PopCap Party Pack, and Zuma Deluxe (ZD) was the one I really didn't want. I've played this style of marble-shooter before, and it's never jived with me. There's just something I dislike about the gameplay, so it really has little to do with any specific version of the game, it's applicable to all of them. One disliked game out of five didn't make it a better deal to buy the others separately though, so I got the entire pack regardless. 


[h1]Gameplay[/h1] 
Each stage places the stone frog in a central location, with a pathway in place for the line of marbles to advance. Since it's sort of like a passage for water to traverse, it can take on any sort of shape, with a tendency to curve and bend quite a lot. Starting out, there are only four colors of marble to deal with, so shooting your marble at a set of at least three to clear them is rather easy. Plus, with such little variety, destroying any section will more likely lead to the two sections on either side to be the same color. When that's the case, the line of marbles comes together, and the matching colors will combine and be destroyed. If the other parts next to those sections match, it'll keep a chain reaction going, until the colors are different. It doesn't take long for more colors to be added, which makes this harder to pull off. 


[h1]Controls[/h1] 
Due to how old the game is, it's not surprising that it doesn't work with a controller. However, I didn't notice any problems when I was using my mouse to aim my shots. Sometimes I'd miss, but those were my mistakes at play, not the controls screwing up. 


[h1]Story[/h1] 
The store page indicates this is all supposed to take place in the realm of Zuma, but since that's a made-up location, I interpret the scenery as more of an Aztec civilization. It wouldn't surprise me, as the developers exaggerated matters by using the opposite letter of the alphabet for their society. Either way, your stone frog shooting at a conga line of malicious marbles doesn't contain any story elements. You do progress through ancient temples, but there's no plot or explanation for what's going on. Then again, it really should be self-explanatory. 


[h1]Visuals[/h1] 
One issue with ZD is that its visuals look dated, as it was originally released in 2006. Stages often have the look of stone, and the textures look drab and faded, as if this was never something ZD ever handled well. Even though the statues and stone frog are depicted with big smiles, I think they actually look a tad bit creepy instead of endearing. Maybe it's because they're so stationary, having some appearance of life, while moving so little. Unless I really enjoyed the gameplay, the game's visuals would be a bit of a turn-off and prohibit me from wanting to play it very much. 


[h1]Sound Design[/h1] 
Whatever society this may or may not represent, they're all dead anyways, so who really cares? If the music is too groovy and would have made them shudder because they just weren't hip enough for it, we're not really missing out on them not being around. On that note, I've no idea if the music would be offensive to anybody because it doesn't take its inspiration seriously enough or whatever. Regardless, I and many other people really enjoy listening to the songs in ZD, as they have a contagious nature to them. Instead of playing the game, I might just download some of the songs I enjoy.


[h1]Pros[/h1] 
🌟 As far as puzzle games go, it's a lot more action-based. Ironic, as these quicker games tend to be my preferred style. 
🌟 The occasional power-up helps deal with the increasing difficulty. 


[h1]Cons[/h1] 
❌ Being a bit of a broken record, but for being a deluxe version, there's not many features in the game. There are no trading cards, achievements, and I wasn't able to take any screenshots either. 
❌ It doesn't take long before you start having to contend with quite a few colors at the same time. It inhibits your ability to make chains and greatly increases the difficulty. 


[h1]Tips[/h1]
🔍 At any time, you'll have two colors that you can shoot. The one in your mouth is what you'll shoot, while the one on your back is what you could exchange for and fire instead.  
🔍 Time your shots carefully. You have to account for the forward movement of the marbles while aiming. 
🔍 If you're not fully surrounded, you can shoot useless marbles off the screen. 


[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1] 
Seeing as how this game was one I actively didn't want, especially because I innately dislike the kind of game it is, it's not really possible for me to say whether its a good version or not. From the thousands of good reviews, which I assume aren't solely based on nostalgia, it's likely on the same level of quality as the other games from the same pack. Looking at it another way, for those who are fond of puzzle games, you're likely to agree with the majority and enjoy ZD, but you could be an oddball like me and dislike shooting marbles. Because I don't believe there's anything truly wrong with the game, even if I don't enjoy it, I'll recommend it. Personally, it's the least interesting game from the PopCap Party Pack, but at least it works on my PC. Sorry Mac users.

128738957.review: This is a fun mouse-only, single-screen, colored ball, shooter style game that takes between 30 seconds and 5 minutes to clear a screen.  The balls follow a pre-defined curved path that snakes and loops across the screen.  Shooting a distant loop through a gap is a fun challenge as are shooting coins which require careful color coded shooting and timing to hit them.  The background music is actually pretty good, sets the mood and is not obtrusive.  The game tracks your best time and presents that at the scoring screen along with the "Ace" time which gives you a reminder and challenge even on replays. Overall the game is fun diversion that can find you wondering how it got to be 2AM when clearly it was you thinking "just one more level".

115788514.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 35.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

109204019.review:
One of the best in its genre, a real classic. I played it a lot in my childhood, so it was nice to finally buy it and play it.

First of all, the game has a gigantic difficulty spike around stage 10-11. Other reviews mention stage 8 or 9 as breaking points, for me personally that was still fine. 

During the game I collected I think 20 extra lives. In stage 10, I lost 9 in 3 levels. 
I finished the game (after earning another 2) with 3. Three.

RNG rules the last stages - the line curves back onto itself, blocking shots. There's been examples of not getting a colour to hit a slow-combo for about 20 shots. The colour variety, and speed of the balls make sure to add up the difficulty and make your mistakes pile up extremely fast.   Fail the same level 4-5 times, then do it finally well under half of the ace time.

I write a negative review to point out this issue. Other reviews mention a high framerate problem, which makes the game run too fast, hence the difficulty - maybe one could limit the framerate through GPU's program.  But as the game is out of the box, it needs cautionary reviews because the difficulty spike. If you're okay with that, just buy it. 

(Though seems like it doesn't run on Mac, despite the requirements. Check old negative reviews)

109106019.review:
I would absolutely NOT recommend getting this game, not even if it's heavily discounted, which it was at the time of purchasing it (Lunar New Year, 2022).

So, why's that? Technical problems? Nope. Runs fine on Win10, no issues there whatsoever.

The problem with this game, is that the spike in difficulty makes you want to throw it in the trash. Ever played Cuphead? Now, that's a game that has one of the most unique artstyles around and jaw-droppingly gorgeous animation to boot and a cute story. It'll grab you - but you quickly find out that you have to spend hours on getting through single bosses. 

"Oh, but that's just YOU, git gud m8!" - wrong. According to HowLongToBeat.com - average completion of the Main Story is 10.5hrs. Meanwhile, look up a longplay of Cuphead on YouTube (not to be confused with speedruns) - and you'll see it takes 1.5hrs to beat. 

All the charm of it will die off in a hurry. And worse still - because there's no ability to complete the game on "Simple" (aka Easy) - you're stuck with what you got. No way around it.

Zuma Deluxe features no difficulty slider - so in the same vein, you're stuck with what you've got. It all depends on the algorithm/programming/math of the stage/level you're playing. 

There are SO many threads from over the years, not just on Steam - of people pointing out how insane the difficulty curve is in this game. The breaking point for people seem to be around Stage 8 or 9. There are people saying they've spent WEEKS trying to solve individual levels in these stages, along with those who've decided to turn their backs on the game entirely because it was so difficult at this juncture.

I'm not about to spend potentially weeks to get through the remaining parts of the game (I made it to stage 8, level 4) - so I've requested Steam issue me a refund, which they probably won't due to my playtime. If I can't get a refund - I'll request the game be removed permanently from my account. Either way, I'm done with this.

102074522.review:
This is THE old-school PopCap game, and in my opinion it's the best game the company ever put out. Despite the appearance of it just being a standard PopCap puzzle game, the frenetic and stressful gameplay gives Zuma Deluxe a hook that'll make you want to come back for more, even years later. Compared to their other work, it shocks me how little this game is discussed online. I used to play it all the time as a kid from a CD before I eventually purchased it on Steam, and coming back to it reveals that despite some compatibility and scaling issues (more on those later), the core gameplay hasn't aged a day.

It feels like a Japanese arcade-puzzle game at it's core, and that's because, well, it is one. Zuma Deluxe is infamously derivative of Puzz Loop, an arcade game from the 90s that has the same basic concept and gameplay. The developers even admitted in interviews that they got the idea for Zuma by playing Puzz Loop in MAME. The emphasis on chaining, scoring, and the lives system, things that weren't given immediate gameplay relevance in other games by PopCap (you NEED to hit a certain score threshold in a level to be able to end it, more on this later) can all be traced back to the game's arcade roots, as well as the very high difficulty of later stages. It's almost an unfair comparison to make, but it absolutely puts Puzz Loop to shame. Zuma Deluxe feels like it hit the sweet spot of gameplay improvements that turned Puzz Loop into the intense, fast-paced, challenging game that it needed to be, without going into gimmick territory and turning into Zuma's Revenge. Whether it's ethical to essentially remake someone else's game and comparatively make a killing from it, even if it is vastly improved, is up to you.

The real depth of Zuma Deluxe comes from the fact that just trying to power through and go for easy clears isn't enough to survive later on when the game starts throwing in new colors to deal with. You need to get familiar with and take advantage of the opportunities for bonus points and powerups the game gives you in order to make it out alive, which gives a much greater feeling of accomplishment when completing the stage than other PC puzzle games where developing that kind of intentionality isn't so important. Setting up chains, gap bonuses, and gaps in specific areas to be able to snag coins when they show up is absolutely critical to hitting that score threshold where the chorus yells "ZUMA!" and stops spawning new spheres to clear. Unlike other games by PopCap, you don't have the luxury of playing at your own pace, and it can be very nerve-wracking the last few seconds where you realize that you've found yourself in an impossible position, where nothing you do can save you from losing a life.

The fact that this is almost pulled right from a game center can be a turn-off for some people, though. There's basically no story or characters to speak of here, and the fact that you need to play through almost every level four times during the arcade mode means that you'll get real familiar with every level in this game whether you like every one of those levels or not. Each time it loops, you either get a new color (for visits 2 and 3) or the speed at which the balls move increases (visit 4). You also get a new bonus level for each stage, but having to play through 5 or 6 levels of repeating content to see the next one makes the arcade mode of this game feel way longer than it needs to be. Having to play Codex of Mixtec for the 4th time in a single sitting might have been last push someone needed before they finally snapped. It seems like it would have been wise to make these different runs individual difficulty modes instead, but hindsight is 20/20. What also might have benefited from hindsight is the game's general aesthetic. I'm very nostalgic for it, but going into the future I doubt people will find it very tasteful. When I think about it too hard, it almost reminds me of the racist video slots that old people waste thousands on in casinos.

Going back to the topic of compatibility, this game came out in 2003, and released on Steam in 2006. It's not really designed to adapt to more modern computers, and while you could get lucky and not have to look up any issue or guide to have a good time, you might need to dig around the support forum or the guides on Steam, or do some Googling to get everything working 100% properly. It shouldn't be a huge challenge, but you should be aware of this before purchasing the game. Fortunately, this also means that the system requirements are some of the lowest on the platform.

Despite its flaws, this game for $5 is a really good deal. If they patched it up a bit and made it a better experience to play on modern computers, it might even be worth $15. It's a diamond in the rough, and for the price, it'll be worth it even if it doesn't hook you, and you just play it for a few hours before putting it down.

100072078.review:
(English - Solution / Español - Solución) 
I tried a lot and I "finally" have a way to play it. This is what I do:
- I copied the file "Steam.dll" from the Steam folder and then pasted it in Zuma folder.
- I changed the compatibility of zuma.exe to "Windows Vista" (No Service pack), but without executing as administraror. So, this configuration change doesn't quit Steam interface or taking screenshots. 
- When I am going to start a new game and the screen keeps in black and "loading", I click on the bellow right corner, when the mouse changes its icon. This allows me to play 

La configuración que obtuve después de mucho probar es la siguiente:
- Copiar el archivo "Steam.dll" de la carpeta principal de Steam y pegarlo en la carpeta de Zuma.
- Cambiar la compatibilidad de zuma.exe a la de "Windows Vista" (No Service Pack), pero sin cambiarlo también a que se ejecute como administrador. Este cambio no afecta el acceso a la interfaz de Steam ni a la toma de capturas.
- Es muy probable que al iniciar o cargar una partida la pantalla se quede en negro y aparezca el cursor titilando y "cargando". Lo que hay que hacer es moverlo a la esquina inferior derecha hasta que cambie la forma y hacer clic, lo cual ya permite jugar.

De resto, el juego es bastante adictivo y muy divertido y desafiante, además de que no pesa casi nada.

I played this game so long ago. This was one of the first games i played as a kid. Its a really simple and fun game. You have colored balls and these balls move on a set path towards a hole. You have to destroy these balls before they reach the hole or you lose. Destroying them is easy. Just match the colors. 2 blue colors are moving towards the hole and you are about to fire a blue ball ? Well fire it at those 2 same colored balls and when you hit them they will explode. They have to be the same color tho if you fire a blue ball at 2 red balls nothing will happen cuz the colors are different. You match 3 balls that are the same color. The more you match, the more points you'll get and the more balls you destroy the easier the level will be. After all balls are destroyed you'll win. Its simple.

+Its a really fun, short game. Something you can play when you're bored and there is nothing else you wanna do.
+It starts of really easy but it does get complicated as time goes on.

+/- No fullscreen support. When you do open fullscreen the resolution might be wrong. Its not really needed i think playing the game in fullscreen isn't good playing it in a windowed screen is more fun and easier to use. For me this isn't a huge problem but for others this could be a problem.

-The full price 10 Turkish Lira isn't really worth it. I bought it in a 80% sale which was 2 Turkish Lira which is good enough for me. But again the full price is a bit too much.

Its a fun, small, quick game. Something you can play when you have nothing else to do, when you are bored. Wait for a discount before buying.

94897520.review:
Zuma is essentially Puzzle Bobble on a track. The balls will slowly revolve until they reach the center, at which point you will lose. However, to stop the advance of the line of balls, you can fire a ball into the queue. Three balls of the same colour in a row will destroy the balls and create a gap in the line, stopping the flow of all the balls ahead until the gradual pushing of the line reaches the point at which you broke the queue. There are power-up balls which will activate upon destruction, but they don't make a massive difference until the late game where you're pressed for time. The game is not difficult.

Zuma Deluxe is the original Zuma. It shows its age, running at what I presume is 1024 x 768, with very basic graphics acceleration (you won't need a discrete GPU in 2021 for this), which can be turned off if you prefer the look. I think seeing the pixels at such a low resolution adds to the charm. You get one other option, which is to use a custom golden cursor.

So is it worth it? It's so cheap on sale (under a euro), that it's basically free. Is it worth playing? I mean, there's nothing amazing going on here, but it'll kill 10 minutes. Basically, it's a decent game for next-to-nothing. I wouldn't pay full price, but if you're a die-hard PopCap fan, a collector, or just really itch to play some Zuma, go for it.

In short, it's decent. That's pretty much it.

94293884.review:
It is what it is, everyone should know what Zuma is, right?
For those that don't, is it a form of match-3 game, but the marbles are a long chain, slowly following a path towards the center, and you are trying to make sure the front marble doesn't make it. 
Like old time arcade games, you do have multiple lives, and can earn more with good scores. 
When you can, you try to remove a set that matching colors in front of and behind it, as the forward most stretch of chain will snap back. If they combine to make a group of more than three, they will also vanish. With luck you can create quit the chain reaction.
You also have two marbles to choose from at any time, the one in the mouth, and the one in his back that you can switch out with a right click. Sometimes they are the same color, but them's the breaks, as they say.
There are also power-ups, if you can get them, though they are often behind the chain and you need to create a break in the chain to reach them.
If you want to test it, there are free versions online. FB has them. I wanted my own, and it was on sale, so it was worth it.
The graphics here are not the sharpest, however, it really looks like it is from 2006, or even before then.
I find it fun little addictive diversion though, and it is easy to recommend.

91719042.review:
[h1]Game is anything, but casual[/h1]

Under colourful veneer lies one of most RNG dependent Popcap game. It might look easy and relaxing at first, but it is one of the most intense game you can find. On the last levels, there is no room for error, but because how RNG works in this game, most of your runs are destined to fail. Power ups do not spawn. Wrong power ups. Power ups spawn, but ball does not. Ball has an autistic tendency to be spawn the same, especially when you have nowhere to put it. You will often find yourself in situation where you are close to losing and game decides to spawn balls which you do not need or even can't place them. One green ball at the end of the chain which you can't reach? 4 GREEN BALLS IN THE ROW! In a similar matter lines are being spawned. Sometimes they come in long mono coloured lines, in other times they are mixed with only few balls to pop. 

Game at the highest level is all about RNG. There is something fundamentally wrong mechanically in game when you can almost double Ace time in this game and still have not a slightest idea why you lost. Sometimes you make mistakes and win, other times it is hopeless from the very start. Game does not leave you time to think, to play with smash mechanic to reverse flow of the balls. It is all about speed at which you can perform and hope for the best that game does not decide to screw you.


Another issue is that there is no way to come back in this game. If balls roll almost into the mouth, any other ball is likely to push them into it and you lose. This means that you can't fix your situation after a certain point.


This video explains the fundamental issue with Zuma and that is its RNG:

https://youtu.be/Alw5hs0chj0


[b]In conclusion[/b] 

In might be good for nostalgia trip, but there is a reason why nobody had copied this formula and it is because game is frustrating when you play it a lot. Half of my playtime is in two last levels. I played for 4 hours in 12 1-4 levels. It is very frustrating experience when you ramp up difficulty, you should just quit when game gets hard, because otherwise it will just ruin any good impression this game had.

A good game to play once in a while when you want some Match 3 fun. The later levels (starting at the third set of levels for me) can create a pretty steep difficulty curve, especially when the balls move at high-speed every time they are not in the danger zone. The repetition of earlier levels on the later stages can also grind onto your soul after a while.

Other than the difficulty curve and repetition, the game is pretty cheap and simple to play and can be a good breather, as long as you get used to seeing that skull open its mouth to the danger music.

77399960.review:
Truly a classic

A one-of-a-kind game that mixes action and puzzle perfectly in it's own way.

The mechanics are very easy to understand, but as the speed gradually ramps up and more different colors enter the scene as you progress through the game, the more challenging it gets to the point that you almost have to give up thinking and rely on your first instinct to keep those balls away from that accursed skull...
I especially found the last two temples frustrating, but I found it very rewarding the moment I finally beat that last obstacle and cleared the game.

The only downside is the fact that you have to face the same levels again after you beat the 3rd and 6th temple (the only difference is the bigger speed and a new color), but i find that personally a minor detail in the end. 

Overall a must-have for those who like to play fast-paced action-puzzles and for those who love to casually play a game.

The goal is to clear the board before the balls get swallowed by whatever creature resides in the drain. The music is initially fun, but quickly becomes annoying. (Luckily, you can adjust the volume of the music.) The sound of the balls clanking together is very satisfying. Imagine the sound of balls clanking together on a pool table. If you like casual games that *don't* demand constant buy-ups or spamming your friends to proceed through the game, try Zuma.

So I bought this game while it was on sale during halloween because I'd thought I play something else for a while.

After downloading I booted the game up and started to play.
Stage 1 - 3 Seemed quite easy as things had started off simple, and while for Stage 4 - 5 Added another color to match (Magenta) it still felt a little too easy. Stage 6 felt like it had a little more challenge added to it but still didn't please me much; I then played Stage 7 seeing that the difficulty had increased also adding another color to match (Grey), stage 7 felt like quite the challenge and luckily I got through it! Although I tried stage 8 and I was getting quite a few game over's. . .ok more than a few but I tried and tried to get passed stage 8 but the best I could manage was completing up to Level 8-3, Level 8-4 just couldn't seemed to get passed.

If talking about the story it didn't feel like if there was any story even when completing stage 3 or 6 as it was just a little bit of text and that was that.

The artwork I'd say was good, but the frog felt a tad colorless.

So In the end I would say that I don't recommend this game.

My rating on art,gameplay and story:

Gameplay: 7.75 / 10
Art/Graphics: 8 / 10
Story: 3.85 / 10

FINAL RATING: 
    5.80 / 10

-Angry Waiter 2019

MAC USERS BEWARE!!!
Read the fine print. This game does not work on OS X 10.7 or later. It was written for the old PPC Macs, and only functioned on Intel Macs because of Rosetta, which was removed from the OS in 2011. PopCap never bothered updating it, and EA ignores the Mac.
Go to zumazuma or one of the other sites that has the free browser-based version.

38572806.review:
At the time of writing, I'm playing a lot of games that are quite heavy on the game-mechanics side of things (HeXen, Unreal, Prince of Persia, STALKER) or story (KoTOR II, Mafia).

For me, this is the perfect cooldown from endless dialog trees, droves of enemy types and labyrinths upon labyrinths of levels. Just shoot the on-rails moving balls with your static frog turret so the ball colours match and clear the level before the time runs out. You have some fairly straightforward powerups like slow moving balls and reverse movement direction, then there's accuracy and explosion. Nothing too fancy, but it's so effective as a time killer.

The music is also very fitting, just hype enough to keep your brain firing but still inocuous enough to not make you nervous (unless you're near death, then the music changes and it's meant to make you nervous).

There's an "adventure" mode, where you complete levels by hitting a certain points threshold, and survival mode with four difficulty levels where the balls just keep coming until you lose.

Don't let this fool you into thinking the game is easy, however. It has that patented PopCap balance of challenging, addictive and still enjoyable. Like I said, I love to play it when I don't feel like watching a movie or series but I don't feel like playing some hardcore 90s FPS either.

The only downside is that the levels in this game are saved as 640x480 JPEG files, so there is absolutely no way to change the resolution, let alone aspect ratio. On my 1366x768 laptop screen, it's not as bad, but I imagine it would be pretty jarring on a 1080 or even 1440 screen.

All in all, it's a shame they didn't update the visuals or even just upscale the whole thing, otherwise this game would be perfect - it's a steal during sales anyway, so even with the dated visuals, I recommend it wholeheartedly.

37548289.review:
As one of the PopCap classics from the mid 2000s, Zuma brought me and my family counless fun hours for over a decade.
The gameplay is simple, match three balls of the same color together and get combos, chains or collect randomly appearing coins to increase the yielded score.
There's also a couple of power-ups which appear occasionally which can help you, such as reversing the balls movement, stopping their movement entirely, causing a big explosion which destroys its surrounding balls and an aim help which lets you shoot your balls quicker.

This game is brought down in two modes, the Adventure and a Gauntlet mode (which is pretty much a survival mode).
-The Adventure Mode is a stage-to-stage Level Rush where you have to score a specific amount of points to stop more balls from spawning and then clear the screen to get to the next stage.
All this is split into multiple different worlds with more colors to appear the deeper you get.
-The Gauntlet Mode allows you to play any stage you beat in the Adventure Mode and attempt to survive as long as you can, while attempting to score as much points as possible.

One thing I'd like to mention is the games modability, yes I'm serious!
If you look into the local files, you notice that most image and audio files (except of the background-music unfortunately) use default file extensions and formatting.
This means you can easily replace game files and inplement your own files if you want an entirely new Zuma experience!
I cannot tell you if any format works, but as long as you covert your files into the same extension as they were in Zuma (most of them are .jpg, .gif and .ogg), it should work just fine. (atleast it did for me and a friend of mine)
You might want to backup your save file though prior to the modding, just in case something goes majorly wrong which forces you to re-install the game, thus as always mod at your own risk!

The only problems I have are:
 -Maximum resolution of 640x480, which you can get used to in fullscreen, but can cause trouble when playing in windowed mode. (see next point)
-The game does not force the cursor inside the games window when you don't use fullscreen, hence you can click outside the window accidentaly and not shoot while playing. Trust me, this happens more than you'd wish!
-I honestly believe it's not worth the full price of €5 any more. This game came out 14 years ago and its successor is avaiable for the same price, offering way more.

BUT:
If this game IS on sale, I can only recommend this to anyone as it's a very addictive experience which first up seems very simple, but gets more complex when you get to later stages, both in Adventure and in Gauntlet.
The graphics are ok for its time while the music fits the atmosphere perfectly.
Even if my playtime on Steam isn't that high yet, I can promise you my (and also my parents) time spent into this game would exceed your expectations.

My dad got this game when I was little. Why he decided to get it, I don't know, but I'm glad he did. We played this game religously (he especially played it a lot); it was honestly a part of my childhood gaming experience. For years, I completely forgot this game existed, but just a few days ago, I remembered it. Imagine how happy I was to find out that it was on Steam. 

Starting it up, everything was familiar. The pseudo-Mayincatec music. The cute but dated graphics. The sound effects. The level design. I could recall everything. The gameplay is super simple, but it's fun and addicting. 

Anyway, maybe it's the nostalgia talking, but you should totally get it. It's a fun little time waster.

30985946.review:
Oh my, that's the game that took so many days, and nights, and even some of the work time from me and many of my friends! While it's not really innovative or something, being a bit upgraded version of the Bejeweled... It was Zuma who made me and so many other people possessed!

You know, I'm not really recommending you the game. If you're not a fan of casual games like "match 3", you'll be quite okay without it. And even if you're a fan... Maybe you should not try it. Because yes, it is a poison. The S-grade time consumer. You take a level, then one more, then just one more... Each of them isn't anything really hard, and take about a minute or two... but then, you wake up hours later somewhere on the 8-4 level, and thinking "This one should be the last!". And maybe you'll quit right away. But you'll surely return, and get to the 13th level eventually. And if someday you'll manage that highest 13th too, that accomplishment will be marked in your head on the same scale, as, like, finishing an annual income statement!

I can't give the game any other mark but 10/10, for all the hours of the fun I had with it. Especially when I've played it with my wife, which is generally quite off the gaming. Zuma, basically, is one of those games which made it as part of my life. Only a few other game titles I can place on the same level.

15439302.review: Other game I had contact in my childhood. This was my second PopCap game and it is other great puzzle game. Although it was heavily inspired in Puzzle Loop I really like PopCap's version. The goal is to control a (stone?) frog that sends coloured balls to destroy others of the same colour, and all of this to free a god from a spell and be accepted among them. It is fun and addictive, but it is a really difficult game. The Adventure mode gets progressily hard by adding more colours, harder maps and reaching "Zuma!" takes longer. Be prepared for frustration after you clear the first two temples! Then there is the Gauntlet mode where it works as a survival mode and you try to break your own records as soon as you unlock more maps. And sadly it is all what Zuma Deluxe offers so expect repetitiveness. If you enjoy a casual puzzle game but yet challenging, Zuma Deluxe is worth a trial.

13873644.review:
I remember getting trial versions of this game on older computers and playing the crap out of this game.  It was fun, addicting, and could put you in a daze very quickly.

Zuma Deluxe is a puzzle game where you control a rotating from from a top down view in what looks like an ancient Aztec/Mayan temple of sorts.  There is a track on the screen that has multicolored balls moving through the track.  The objective is to shoot colored balls from the mouth of the rotating frog onto balls along the track.  Once three or more colors are formed together from a ball from the frog's mouth, the balls disappear.  But watch out!  There is an end to the track!  So as your balls move along this track, if you don't lessen the line of the track, then you could easily find yourself in the losers pit.

My big deal is that I have played this game countless times before.  I didn't want to play through every single level ever all over again.  No big deal!  I played the first and second level, and the AI recognized my skill level and asked me if I would like to go to a level more fitting for my skill level.  Nothing makes me happier when a game recognizes my ability to play at a higher difficulty, and tailors itself to that difficulty.

Make no mistake.  This game isn't a serious buy.  If you want something to pass the time, or get bored by the expensive AAA titles, pick up this game and give it a whirl.  If you hate time passing puzzle games, then you might not like this game.  I will never uninstall this title though.  Never.  Not even to make room for Deus Ex: Human Revoution.

1188232.review:
One of the old kings of casual gaming, right there next to Bejeweled, and unsuprisingly made by Pop Cap as well.

You shoot colored balls inbetween other colored balls to match three or more of the same color and make them disappear.  You have to make all the balls disappear before they get to the end of the track to pass each stage and the quicker you do it, the more points you get.

Pretty fun, pretty simple, it gets difficult fast as coarses begin to wind around themselves and colors are added so expect a moderate to difficult challenge through most of the game.
